scopecontent.p: This is the manuscript section of that portion of Du Simitiere's collection purchased at auction March 10, 1785. The books and pamphlets bought at the same auction have been dispersed through the Library Company's collections. These manuscripts were gathered or copied by Du Simitiere during his travels in the West Indies, Boston, New York, and during the years he lived in Philadelphia, where he was a member of and one of the curators of the APS. After purchase by the LCP, the manuscripts were bound together and they remain in that order today. Those volumes were described by the Historical Records Survey of the WPA in "Descriptive Catalogue of the Du Simitiere Papers in the Library Company of Philadelphia" (1940), from which the following descriptions have been abstracted. Papers relating to Natural History written between 1763-1773 in Du Simitiere's hand: catalogues, descriptions, and bibliographical references to plants, animals, and some archaeological specimens in North and South America, but particularly Santo Domingo. [In French.] Papers relating to New York consist of copies made by Du Simitiere of documents concerning Leisler's Rebellion and the subsequent controversy over Lord Bellomont's administration, 1689-1712. There are also some copies of early New Netherland records, and a list of coach owners in New York, 1770. [In Dutch and English.] Leisler papers published in Collections of The New York Historical Society. Papers relating to Pennsylvania, the Carolinas, etc. contains 38 manuscripts, probably written 1753-1778, concerning Indian life and history, and travel, including a copy of Lewis Evans' description of Pennsylvania, 1753 and George Croghan's Ohio journal, 1749 [In 2001 LCP alerted survey staff that this journal, along with two other documents -- Statement of John Patten, and "A Brief Account of Pennsylvania, in a letter to Richard Peters, Esqr…" is missing]. Indian Treaties, 1721-1756: originals and contemporary copies in several hands of minutes of councils held in Philadelphia, New York, and elsewhere between the English and the Six Nations, together with relevant correspondence from Conrad Weiser, William Shirley, James DeLancey, Robert Hunter Morris and others. Original letters, 1660-1781. A miscellaneous volume which includes some material not collected by DuSimitiere: 2 letters from Pope Alexander VIII to King James II, 1689, 6 letters of Tobias Smolett, 1761-1770, and others once part of the Henry Cox gift. The remainder of the volume appears to have been gathered by Du Simitiere: letters of colonial committees of correspondence, and documents relating to the revolt of the Pennsylvania line, 1781. Papers relating to the West Indies. Notes and sketches done by Du Simitiere including a description, in French, of Java and of Batavia, with map; descriptions of Jamaica, St. Eustatius, Cuba, Santo Domingo; compilations of Creole dialects; and three watercolors of Kingston, c. 1760. Original journals and extracts. Miscellaneous compendium of travel journals: Susquehanna (1769) and Ottowa (1775); notes and accounts of the Sullivan expedition, 1779; extracts from travel accounts of Captain Cook in the Pacific and Thurberg's account of Japan; and Du Simitiere's copies of verses by John Moylem. Includes several wash drawings of Indian dwellings and writings. Papers relating to New England, New York, etc. Materials gathered and copied by Du Simitiere for a history of New York, with some notes on Pennsylvania, New Jersey and New England. Papers relating to Pennsylvania and New England. Additional materials gathered or copied Du Simitiere relating to Pennsylvania and other parts of British North America. Of special interest are the several bibliographies of the books available to Du Simitiere. Scraps (3 boxes) of highly miscellaneous materials, about one-third of which were copied by Du Simitiere from other sources. Drawings, journals, poems, and particularly, vocabularies and notes on North American Indians.
